tn.text: Samuel has renewed Saul's kingdom at Gilgal and Samuel has reminded the people to follow the Lord.

tn.ref: Saul was thirty years old ... over Israel
tn.text: The text of this verse in ancient copies seems to have been mutilated, so modern versions have many different translations. They are all attempts to represent the most probable meaning of the original text.
"chose 3,000 men" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

tn.ref: Two thousand were with him in Michmash
tn.text: "2,000 were with him in Mishmash" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
Gibeah is a town. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:1sa:10:26|10:26]].

tn.ref: The rest of the soldiers he sent home
tn.text: "He sent the rest of the soldiers home"
"military base of the Philistines" or "military camp of the Philistines"
This is the name of the town that the Philistine garrison was stationed in. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: All Israel heard that Saul had defeated
tn.text: Possible meanings are that 1) Saul was taking responsibility for Jonathan's actions or 2) Saul was taking credit for Jonathan's actions.

tn.ref: Israel had become a rotten smell to the Philistines
tn.text: The Philistines hating the Israelites is spoken of as if the Israelites had become a bad smell that offended the Philistines. AT: "the Philistines hated the Israelites" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: the soldiers were summoned together to join Saul at Gilgal
tn.text: This can be stated in active form.  AT: "Saul called the soldiers together to join him at Gilgal" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"3,000 ... 6,000" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

tn.ref: troops as numerous as the sand on the seashore
tn.text: a group of soldiers so large that it was difficult to count them (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
This is the name of a place. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This is the name of a place. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
The Philistines had gathered together to fight against Israel.
This phrase refers to the nation of Israel.
"the people worried greatly"
The people were greatly afraid.
"according to the time Samuel had told them he would come"

tn.ref: the people were scattering from Saul
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "the people had started to leave Saul" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: Then he offered the burnt offering
tn.text: Only the line of Aaron was permitted to perform the burnt offering sacrifice to God.
Samuel was not really asking a question, but giving a rebuke to Saul. Saul sought to defend his actions even though they were wrong. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
Michmash is the name of a place. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:1sa:13:01|13:02]].

tn.ref: You have not kept the command of Yahweh
tn.text: Saul was to wait for Samuel to come and sacrifice the burnt offering to God. He was not to perform the sacrifice himself.
"set up your rule" or "authorized your rule" or "appointed your rule"
This is a litotes that can be stated in the positive form. AT: "your rule will end soon" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]])

tn.ref: a man after his own heart
tn.text: Here "heart" represents Yahweh's desire or will. The phrase "man after his own heart" is an idiom that means to be a person who does what Yahweh desires. AT: "a man who is the kind of person he wants" or "a man who will obey him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This is an idiom for "Samuel left and went up." (UDB). (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Gilgal is a city. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:1sa:07:15|7:15]].
Gibeah is a town. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:1sa:10:26|10:26]].
"600 men" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
Geba is a town. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:1sa:13:03|13:03]].
Michmash is the name of a place. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:1sa:13:01|13:02]].
Raiders are normally military people who attack enemy villages for their food and other supplies.

tn.ref: Ophrah, to the land of Shual ... Bethhoron ... Valley of Zeboim
tn.text: These are the names of places. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
The narrative shifts to background information regarding blacksmiths in Israel.
This can be stated in active form. AT: "No one could find a blacksmith" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Here "blacksmith" refers to someone who made or sharpened metal tools and weapons.
The words "plow points" refer to the point of a metal tool used for digging up the ground for planting crops.
These are common garden tools.
A "mattock" is a broad-bladed axe, with a horizontal blade that is used for breaking up hard soil.
a curved blade for cutting grasses and grain stalks
thirds of a shekel** - The shekel is divided into 3 parts, 2 of 3 parts are given. "2/3 of a shekel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_bmoney]])
"taking out the bend and making the ox goad straight again so it could be used"
The narrative continues.

tn.ref: there were no swords or spears
tn.text: This explains in part why Saul's army was afraid. They did not have any weapons to fight.
